articles.headline: Is It Time to Have a Money Talk, Child to Parent?
articles.snippet: Grown children often don’t know how the devastation in the markets has affected their parents, and vice versa.
articles.abstract: Grown children often don’t know how the devastation in the markets has affected their parents, and vice versa.
articles.lead_paragraph: The federal bailouts of the last few months raise a variety of thorny questions, including who benefits at whose expense. But the question that hits home the hardest is the one that isn’t getting enough discussion around kitchen tables:

articles.headline: For Women, Red Flags About a Hip Device
articles.snippet: Studies have repeatedly shown a higher failure rate for women who undergo the technique known as hip resurfacing.
articles.abstract: Studies have repeatedly shown a higher failure rate for women who undergo the technique known as hip resurfacing.
articles.lead_paragraph: Even as patients in this country continue to undergo an increasingly popular alternative to traditional hip replacement surgery, medical researchers both here and abroad are raising warning flags about the technique’s use in women.

articles.headline: Turkey Tries to Resist Aid From I.M.F.
articles.snippet: Turkey is faced with the awkward prospect of being forced to accept stringent fiscal conditions to obtain I.M.F. money to replace its disappearing private capital.
articles.abstract: Turkey is faced with the awkward prospect of being forced to accept stringent fiscal conditions to obtain I.M.F. money to replace its disappearing private capital.
articles.lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL  Not so long ago, countries like Turkey  fast-growing but prone to missteps  would go hat in hand to the International Monetary Fund during just about every big financial crisis to beg for money to bail them out of their difficulties.

articles.headline: Once Just an Aging Sign, Falls Merit Complex Care
articles.snippet: For some, a fall sets off a downward spiral of physical and emotional problems that becomes too much to withstand.
articles.abstract: For some, a fall sets off a downward spiral of physical and emotional problems that becomes too much to withstand.
articles.lead_paragraph: MEDFORD, N.J.  Katherine Aliminosa, 93, shattered her lower leg while getting snacks for her nieces.

articles.headline: 75 Years Later, a Nation Hopes for Another F.D.R.
articles.snippet: In the face of an economic abyss, America is in need of a leader like Franklin D. Roosevelt who can both unite and inspire.
articles.abstract: In the face of an economic abyss, America is in need of a leader like Franklin D. Roosevelt who can both unite and inspire.
articles.lead_paragraph: “We are facing the greatest economic challenge of our lifetime, and we’re going to have to act swiftly to resolve it.”

articles.headline: U.S. Jobless Rate Hits 14-Year High
articles.snippet: The toll of lost jobs rose to 1.2 million for the year as 240,000 American jobs disappeared in October.
articles.abstract: The toll of lost jobs rose to 1.2 million for the year as 240,000 American jobs disappeared in October.
articles.lead_paragraph: In a sign that American workers may face even more difficult times for many months to come, the nation’s unemployment rate last month jumped to the highest level in 14 years as job losses mounted.

articles.headline: Green Plans in Blueprints of Retailers
articles.snippet: More stores are building environmentally friendly outlets, as a way to curry favor with consumers and to lower operating costs.
articles.abstract: More stores are building environmentally friendly outlets, as a way to curry favor with consumers and to lower operating costs.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHICAGO  In new Wal-Mart stores, the baseboards and moldings are made of plastic left over from diaper manufacturing. Chipotle, the burrito chain, has installed an energy-producing wind turbine outside a new store in the Chicago suburbs. And a Florida chain called Pizza Fusion reuses the draft from its ovens to heat water.

articles.headline: U.S. Buying More Loans to Students
articles.snippet: The government will expand purchases of the student loans it backs to head off a potential shortfall going into the next school year.
articles.abstract: The government will expand purchases of the student loans it backs to head off a potential shortfall going into the next school year.
articles.lead_paragraph: The government announced plans Friday to expand purchases of the student loans it backs in an effort to head off a potential shortfall next year.
articles.byline: By Jonathan D. Glater and Eric Dash

articles.headline: Citing Workload, Public Lawyers Reject New Cases
articles.snippet: Public defenders’ offices in at least seven states are refusing to take new cases or have sued to limit them.
articles.abstract: Public defenders’ offices in at least seven states are refusing to take new cases or have sued to limit them.
articles.lead_paragraph: MIAMI  Public defenders’ offices in at least seven states are refusing to take on new cases or have sued to limit them, citing overwhelming workloads that they say undermine the constitutional right to counsel for the poor.

articles.headline: Harsh Words About Obama? Never Mind Now
articles.snippet: Many of those who said Barack Obama was anti-American or a friend of terrorists have been changing their tone.
articles.abstract: Many of those who said Barack Obama was anti-American or a friend of terrorists have been changing their tone.
articles.lead_paragraph: That whole anti-American, friend-to-the-terrorists thing about President-elect Barack Obama? Never mind.

articles.headline: An Artist in Exile Tests India’s Democratic Ideals
articles.snippet: A controversial artist’s case illustrates how freedom of expression has frequently come under fire in India.
articles.abstract: A controversial artist’s case illustrates how freedom of expression has frequently come under fire in India.
articles.lead_paragraph: DUBAI, United Arab Emirates  Maqbool Fida Husain, India’s most famous painter, is afraid to go home.

articles.headline: How the Thundering Herd Faltered and Fell
articles.snippet: Merrill Lynch couldn’t escape the housing crash as record waves of homeowners defaulted on their mortgages.
articles.abstract: Merrill Lynch couldn’t escape the housing crash as record waves of homeowners defaulted on their mortgages.
articles.lead_paragraph: “We’ve got the right people in place as well as good risk management and controls.”   E. Stanley O’Neal, 2005

articles.headline: Deported in a Coma, Saved Back in U.S.
articles.snippet: Antonio Torres’s case illustrates the haphazard way that the health care system handles uninsured immigrants.
articles.abstract: Antonio Torres’s case illustrates the haphazard way that the health care system handles uninsured immigrants.
articles.lead_paragraph: GILA BEND, Ariz. — Soon after Antonio Torres, a husky 19-year-old farmworker, suffered catastrophic injuries in a car accident last June, a Phoenix hospital began making plans for his repatriation to Mexico.

articles.headline: Open the Door and Turn on the Lights
articles.snippet: A strong first step for President-elect Barack Obama would be to ensure that finance officials operate with more transparency.
articles.abstract: A strong first step for President-elect Barack Obama would be to ensure that finance officials operate with more transparency.
articles.lead_paragraph: OPTIMISM surrounding last week’s election and the promise of a new crew in Washington ran smack into the reality that we are still mired in a wicked financial mess.

articles.headline: Need to Take a Breather? Have a Game Plan
articles.snippet: A sabbatical or leave of absence from a job can make good sense, even in dismal economic times like these.
articles.abstract: A sabbatical or leave of absence from a job can make good sense, even in dismal economic times like these.
articles.lead_paragraph: One of the most coveted of workplace perks is the sabbatical or leave of absence  a way to stray from your job for a time and return with renewed vigor and enthusiasm. To those of us outside academia, however, leaves of absence are rare. Still, a leave can make good sense, even in dismal economic times like these. Today we have a guest column by Barbara Raab, who is currently on a leave of absence from her job at NBC News. She says that before she asked for the time off, she, too, thought that leaves of absence were more fantasy than reality. MARCI ALBOHER

articles.headline: Obama Team Weighs What to Take On First
articles.snippet: Advisers are trying to decide which of Barack Obama’s campaign promises need to be placed on a slower track.
articles.abstract: Advisers are trying to decide which of Barack Obama’s campaign promises need to be placed on a slower track.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  With the economy in disarray and the nation’s treasury draining, President-elect Barack Obama and his advisers are trying to figure out which of his expansive campaign promises to push in the opening months of his tenure and which to put on a slower track.

articles.headline: China Unveils Sweeping Plan for Economy
articles.snippet: China announced plans to spend billions on a wide array of infrastructure and social welfare projects in a bold move aimed at bolstering its economy.
articles.abstract: China announced plans to spend billions on a wide array of infrastructure and social welfare projects in a bold move aimed at bolstering its economy.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI  China announced a huge economic stimulus plan on Sunday aimed at bolstering its weakening economy, a sweeping move that could also help fight the effects of the global slowdown.

articles.headline: Some G.M. Retirees Are in a Health Care Squeeze
articles.snippet: To conserve cash, General Motors will cut lifetime health care for management retirees at the end of this year.
articles.abstract: To conserve cash, General Motors will cut lifetime health care for management retirees at the end of this year.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT  General Motors is living on borrowed time, spending more than $2 billion in cash a month and lobbying for a government bailout to keep it out of bankruptcy.

articles.headline: What Crisis? Some Hedge Funds Gain
articles.snippet: While most hedge funds are sinking into red this year and unsettling the markets in the process, a handful are posting spectacular gains.
articles.abstract: While most hedge funds are sinking into red this year and unsettling the markets in the process, a handful are posting spectacular gains.
articles.lead_paragraph: Bernard V. Drury is a rarity on Wall Street: a hedge fund manager who is making money rather than losing it.

articles.headline: How Obama Tapped Into Social Networks’ Power
articles.snippet: There’s every reason to believe that President-elect Barack Obama will use his network of supporters not just to campaign, but to govern.
articles.abstract: There’s every reason to believe that President-elect Barack Obama will use his network of supporters not just to campaign, but to govern.
articles.lead_paragraph: In February 2007, a friend called Marc Andreessen, a founder of Netscape and a board member of Facebook, and asked if he wanted to meet with a man with an idea that sounded preposterous on its face.

articles.headline: Goodbye Seduction, Hello Coupons
articles.snippet: As the economy rapidly deteriorates, marketers are scrambling to remake their advertising so products seem affordable and sensible.
articles.abstract: As the economy rapidly deteriorates, marketers are scrambling to remake their advertising so products seem affordable and sensible.
articles.lead_paragraph: SASHA TSYRLIN is a location scout who has spent decades finding sites to film television commercials. He used to spend his days in mansions and gated estates.
articles.byline: By Stephanie Clifford and Stuart Elliott

articles.headline: G.I.’s in Remote Afghan Post Have Weary Job, Drawing Fire
articles.snippet: An American outpost near Afghanistan’s border with Pakistan draws attacks away from populated areas.
articles.abstract: An American outpost near Afghanistan’s border with Pakistan draws attacks away from populated areas.
articles.lead_paragraph: COMBAT OUTPOST LOWELL, Afghanistan  The small stone castle, sandbagged and bristling with weapons and American soldiers, rises from a rock spur beside the Landai River. Mountains lean overhead.

articles.headline: Finding Fame With a Prescient Call for Obama
articles.snippet: In an election season of unlikely outcomes, Nate Silver is perhaps the most unlikely media star to emerge.
articles.abstract: In an election season of unlikely outcomes, Nate Silver is perhaps the most unlikely media star to emerge.
articles.lead_paragraph: At 9:46 p.m., blogging on his site FiveThirtyEight.com, Nate Silver called the presidential election for Barack Obama. The television networks followed suit about an hour and 15 minutes later after most polls in Western states closed.

articles.headline: A.I.G. May Get More in Bailout
articles.snippet: The Treasury Department and the Federal Reserve are nearing a deal to invest an additional $40 billion in American International Group, the giant insurer.
articles.abstract: The Treasury Department and the Federal Reserve are nearing a deal to invest an additional $40 billion in American International Group, the giant insurer.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Bush administration was overhauling its rescue of the American International Group on Sunday night, according to people involved in the deal, amid signs that the interest on its current credit line of more than $100 billion was putting too much strain on the ailing insurer.
articles.byline: By Andrew Ross Sorkin and Mary Williams Walsh

articles.headline: Circuit City Seeks Bankruptcy Protection
articles.snippet: Vendors — worried about Circuit City’s ability to pay for its purchases — choked the company’s operations as the critical holiday season got under way.
articles.abstract: Vendors — worried about Circuit City’s ability to pay for its purchases — choked the company’s operations as the critical holiday season got under way.
articles.lead_paragraph: Any retailer that was weak before the economic downturn appears likely to end up as one of its victims. The latest example is Circuit City, one of the nation’s largest electronics retailers, which filed for bankruptcy protection on Monday after months of declining sales.

articles.headline: Fannie Mae Loses $29 Billion on Write-Downs
articles.snippet: The company’s results suggested that home prices are far from a bottom and that the government would probably have to pump tens of billions of dollars into Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac.
articles.abstract: The company’s results suggested that home prices are far from a bottom and that the government would probably have to pump tens of billions of dollars into Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac.
articles.lead_paragraph: All the profits, and then some, that Fannie Mae reaped as home prices soared in recent years vanished in a mere three months, the mortgage giant said on Monday, leaving many analysts wondering where the red ink will end.
articles.byline: By Vikas Bajaj and Charles Duhigg
